newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Oil partners say Nigeria can raise its market share.
newsitem.headline: Oil partners say Nigeria can raise its market share.

text.p: Nigeria's joint venture oil partners believe it can raise its share of the world energy market to five per cent by the year 2010.

"Nigeria's share of world energy market can grow from the three percent level now to five percent by 2010, by increasing production capacity and reserves," the partners said in a joint proposal to a Vision 2010 committee planning Nigeria's future.
Nigeria, a member of OPEC, currently can produce about 2.14 million barrels per day (bpd) of oil with reserves put at 24 billion barrels as at the end of 1996.
Nigeria's joint venture partners are Royal Dutch Shell Group, Mobil Corp, Chevron Corp, Agip SpA, Elf Aquitaine and Texaco Inc.
The government holds an average of 57 percent equity in the local units of the multinationals.

Their joint proposal said Nigeria's government would need to establish and maintain a fiscal framework that would encourage investments as well as an appropriate mechanism for funding the government share of oil exploration and production activities.
The funding options they proposed include reducing the government's holding in its present joint ventures with multinational oil firms in phases and over a period of time to a pre-determined level.
This, they said would do away with the government's present inability to pay cash-calls, its share of the exploration and production costs of the joint ventures that operate Nigeria's oil industry.
"The strategies should see Nigeria's production rising to 4.5 million barrels daily and 50 billion barrels reserve level by the year 2010," their proposal said.
The oil firms said the government should make funding cash-calls a priority basis and all new oil leases should be based on Production Sharing Contracts (PSCs).
Under the PSCs, which are already in operation with some foreign oil firms, the companies fund solely their exploration costs and recover it if oil is struck.
